citations.title: Oshawa Assembly | General Motors ...
citations.summary: In 2023, General Motors announced a C$280 million investment in the Oshawa Assembly plant to enhance the production capabilities for next-generation internal combustion engine (ICE) full-size trucks. This investment is part of GM's broader commitment to Canadian manufacturing, which included over C$1.6 billion invested in the Oshawa facility in 2020.

citations.title: Bundle up: Tips for driving your GM EV in winter
citations.summary: GM electric vehicles are equipped with an advanced thermal management system that regulates battery temperature to ensure optimal performance and longevity. This system automatically adjusts the battery's temperature during charging, warming it in cold conditions and cooling it in hot weather. Additionally, the Eco Climate mode enhances energy efficiency by optimizing cabin heating and cooling.

citations.title: GM and Wolfspeed develop domestically-sourced EV ...
citations.summary: General Motors and Wolfspeed, Inc. have formed a strategic supplier agreement to develop silicon carbide power device solutions for GM's upcoming electric vehicle programs, enhancing the efficiency of EV propulsion systems and extending vehicle range. The silicon carbide devices will be integrated into GM's Ultium Drive units, with production taking place at Wolfspeed's Mohawk Valley Fab in New York, the largest silicon carbide fabrication facility globally. Additionally, GM will engage in the Wolfspeed Assurance of Supply Program to ensure a sustainable and scalable supply of materials for EV production.

citations.title: GM to invest $888 million in Tonawanda Propulsion plant
citations.summary: General Motors is investing $888 million in its Tonawanda Propulsion plant to enhance the production of its sixth-generation V-8 engines, which are utilized in full-size trucks and SUVs. This new engine generation aims to improve performance while also enhancing fuel economy and reducing emissions, primarily through advancements in combustion and thermal management technologies.

citations.title: Ultium Energy Recovery Can Help GM EVs Charge and ...
citations.summary: GM's Ultium energy recovery system utilizes a patented heat pump to capture and repurpose waste heat generated by EV batteries and propulsion components, enhancing vehicle efficiency by powering heating and acceleration while conserving range. This technology, which has its roots in the development of the EV1 in the late 1990s, is protected by 11 patents and is integrated into all current and future Ultium vehicles. Additionally, the system can harness humidity and body heat from passengers to further optimize energy usage.

citations.title: GM's path to full autonomy: Building trust step-by-step
citations.summary: General Motors is advancing its autonomous driving capabilities by expanding its fleet of vehicles that collect real-world data, accumulating thousands of miles daily alongside millions of miles in simulations. This data-driven approach aims to enhance the development of their autonomous systems, including features like Super Cruise, which requires user attention and compliance with specific terms. The company emphasizes the importance of safety and user engagement while utilizing these technologies.
